I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will build financial management 
capacity and help boost the quality of financial due diligence (FDD) to improve the financial 
sustainability of projects funded by the Asian Development Bank (ADB). It will also help improve 
financial management throughout the project cycle in ADB’s Central and West Asia developing 
member countries (DMCs).1 This will be achieved through enhanced guidance to project teams 
and hands-on support to executing and/or implementing agencies, through strategically placed 
regional consultants2 in ADB’s resident missions who will support ADB’s Central and West Asia 
Department Office of the Director General, Portfolio, Results, Safeguards, and Gender Unit 
(CWOD-PSG) to ensure FDD quality. This TA broadly complements efforts of ADB’s Public 
Financial Management Division under the Procurement, Portfolio and Financial Management 
Department (PFFM) to strengthen institutional financial management practices through capacity 
building activities, integrated fiduciary risk assessments, and strengthening of country systems.3 
 
2.  The  2019  Annual  Portfolio  Performance  Report4  highlighted the  need to  strengthen 
financial management in the project cycle and continue to build DMCs’ financial management 
capacity.  The  2019  Annual  Financial  Management  Report5  details  how  robust  financial 
management practices contribute to ADB executing its fiduciary responsibility effectively and 
implementing projects and programs successfully. It concludes that ADB’s financial management 
function has been strengthened from 2017 to 2019, but momentum must be maintained to 
mainstream financial management practices in ADB operations. Through the proposed TA, ADB 
will work closely with DMCs and continue to provide hands-on support to project team leaders 
and executing and/or implementing agencies to improve project FDD during processing and 
strengthen the monitoring of financial compliance. 
 
3.  The TA is not included in the country operations business plans as it is regional. It is well 
aligned  with  ADB’s  Strategy  20306  operational  priority  for  strengthening  governance  and 
institutional capacity of DMCs. The TA will also continue to address the request7 of the Office of 
the President to heads of departments to strengthen financial management.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
4.  Robust FDD during project processing will help DMCs strengthen their decision-making 
capacity to design, finance, and implement ADB-funded projects and programs; improve the 
financial compliance, sustainability, and viability of the implementing projects; contribute to more 
successful outcomes; and provide a greater development impact. Increased attention to the 
effectiveness  of  financial  support  and  financial  sustainability  requires  enhanced  fiduciary 
oversight of funds, and increased fiduciary accountability and responsibility of DMCs, to manage 
financial risks better.  
 
 
1 ADB’s Central and West Asia Department covers Afghanistan, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Georgia, Kazakhstan, the 
Kyrgyz Republic, Pakistan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan. 
2  The TA may recruit regional consultants with specific expertise in ADB public financial management, auditing, and 
financial reporting requirements in groups of countries under ADB’s Central and West Asia Department.

5.  From  2016  to  20019,  the  region  has  experienced  significant  structural  reforms  by 
unbundling  entities  and  creating  new  companies  in  revenue-generating  segments.  These 
changes require comprehensive FDD and the development of robust financial management 
action plans (FMAPs) to mitigate financial risks. Such structural changes will necessitate deeper, 
comprehensive, and more frequent engagement and hands-on support by financial management 
experts  with  executing  and/or  implementing  agencies  and  auditors  during  project  design, 
processing, and implementation.  
 
6.  Most Central and West Asia DMCs are in transition to adopting the International Financial 
Reporting Standards (IFRS) or the International Public Sector Accounting Standards (IPSAS) and 
aligning their national accounting standards with the IFRS and/or IPSAS. This transition is 
challenging because of limited local expertise and lack of comprehensive manuals for executing 
and/or implementing agencies. Additionally, many governance risk assessments for Central and 
West Asia DMCs have identified weak internal audit and internal control country systems. To 
mitigate the risks, the TA will enable the recruitment of consultants to provide (i) hands-on support 
to executing and/or implementing agencies  in setting up project implementation units, and 
(ii) guidance throughout the projects to ensure adequate financial compliance. 
 
7.   ADB  has  previously  made  efforts  to  enhance  the  capacity  of  executing  and/or 
implementing agencies and external auditors in DMCs through targeted  training programs, 
resulting in improved timely submission of audited project financial statements (APFSs) and 
audited entity financial statements (AEFSs). However, challenges remain to ensure acceptable 
quality, improve compliance with financial covenants, and enhance the monitoring of financial 
mitigating measures for better project outcomes.  
 
8.  Finally,  many  financial  management  assessments  result  in  pre-mitigated  substantial 
financial management risks, and require the implementation of time-bound FMAPs that need 
close monitoring and require strong guidance to executing and/or implementing agencies on their 
implementation.  The  TA  consultants  will  provide  hands-on  guidance  to  executing  and/or 
implementing agencies to strengthen the monitoring of FMAPs under the projects. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.   Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: improvements in public expenditure efficiency 
in Central and West Asia DMCs. The TA will have the following outcome: portfolio performance 
in Central and West Asia DMCs improved.  
 
B.   Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
10.  Output 1: Financial due diligence strengthened. This output will (i) improve quality 
assurance processes for FDD during project processing, including conducting comprehensive 
reviews and updates of financial management assessments, and financial analysis and financial 
evaluations, for better financial sustainability; and (ii) provide quality assurance review for entities’ 
financial information for better quality FDD.  
 
11.  Output  2:  Financial  reporting  compliance  improved.  This  output  will  (i)  provide 
guidance to executing and/or implementing agencies on ADB-funded projects’ financial reporting 
requirements; (ii) monitor FMAP implementation and updates; (iii) ensure that APFSs and/or 
AEFSs are submitted on time and are of acceptable quality; (iv) provide advisory services to the

3 
 
entities in the conversion of national accounting standards to IFRS reporting, as needed; and (v) 
provide specialized guidance to new executing and implementing agencies on the IPSAS, project 
financial management, and project internal audit and internal control requirements. 
 
12.  The TA will (i) strengthen executing and/or implementing agencies’ capacity by providing 
guidance on project financial management, (ii) support quality assurance processes for FDD 
during project processing, and (iii) enhance the monitoring of FMAPs and the timely submission 
of APFSs and/or AEFSs during implementation. The TA will also ensure the participation of 
female staff during executing and/or implementing agencies’ guidance and advisory sessions, 
which will be monitored as part of the design and monitoring framework. In addition, it will enable 
centralized quality assurance, focusing on the FDD and financial compliance of all DMCs, which 
will improve project implementation financial management aspects as well as mitigating financial 
management risks for future projects. 
 
13.  TA  management  activities  will  be  continuous  throughout  the  TA,  including  the 
administration and management of consulting contracts, TA reviews, and monitoring. 
 
C.   Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $300,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund ($250,000 from the TASF 6 and $50,000 from TASF-other 
sources). 
 
D.   Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  Under the close guidance and supervision of the CWOD-PSG financial management due 
diligence group, three individual regional consultants will be recruited on an intermittent basis for 
12 person-months each, with possible extensions. The consultants will be placed in ADB’s 
resident missions to (i) support quality assurance processes for FDD during project processing; 
(ii) conduct FDD, on a needs basis; and (iii) provide support to project implementation units for 
setting up financial management systems and monitoring of FMAP actions.

17.  Consulting services. The individual consultants will be engaged competitively. ADB will 
engage the consultants8 following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to 
time) and its associated staff instructions. The TA will commence in the respective DMCs upon 
written confirmation that the government does not object to ADB financing of the TA.9  
 
18.  The TA scope will be reassessed in 2021. Subject to the results of this assessment and 
funding availability, potential avenues for expansion include (i) additional consultants; (ii) the 
development of specialized project financial management manuals to provide guidance on ADB 
requirements  in  English,  with  translations  to  local  and/or  regional  languages;  and  (iii)  the 
development of an internal audit manual.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000 on a grant basis for 
Enhancing Financial Management in Central and West Asia,  and hereby reports this action to 
the Board.
